claims.statement: no-store forces Next.js to fetch the resource from the remote server on every request
claims.source_quote: Next.js fetches the resource from the remote server on every request, even if Dynamic APIs are not detected on the route

claims.statement: auto is the default cache option that fetches once during next build if the route is statically prerendered
claims.source_quote: default: Next.js fetches the resource from the remote server on every request in development, but will fetch once during next build

claims.statement: revalidate option sets the cache lifetime of a resource in seconds
claims.source_quote: Set the cache lifetime of a resource (in seconds)

claims.statement: Setting revalidate to false caches a resource indefinitely
claims.source_quote: Cache the resource indefinitely. Semantically equivalent to revalidate: Infinity

claims.statement: Setting revalidate to 0 prevents a resource from being cached
claims.source_quote: Prevent the resource from being cached

claims.statement: Setting revalidate to a number specifies the cache lifetime in seconds
claims.source_quote: Specify the resource should have a cache lifetime of at most n seconds

claims.statement: tags option allows setting cache tags for on-demand revalidation using revalidateTag
claims.source_quote: Set the cache tags of a resource. Data can then be revalidated on-demand using revalidateTag

claims.statement: Maximum length for a custom cache tag is 256 characters
claims.source_quote: The max length for a custom tag is 256 characters

claims.statement: Maximum number of cache tag items is 128
claims.source_quote: the max tag items is 128

claims.statement: Next.js caches fetch responses in Server Components across HMR in development for faster responses
claims.source_quote: Next.js caches fetch responses in Server Components across Hot Module Replacement (HMR) in local development for faster responses

claims.statement: HMR cache applies to all fetch requests including those with default auto and no-store options
claims.source_quote: the HMR cache applies to all fetch requests, including those with the default auto no cache and cache: 'no-store' option

claims.statement: If Dynamic APIs are detected, the whole route revalidation interval will be decreased
claims.source_quote: If an individual fetch() request sets a revalidate number lower than the default of a route, the whole route revalidation interval will be decreased

claims.statement: Conflicting options like revalidate and no-store are not allowed and will be ignored with a warning
claims.source_quote: Conflicting options such as { revalidate: 3600, cache: 'no-store' } are not allowed, both will be ignored, and in development mode a warning will be printed

claims.statement: In development mode, cache-control: no-cache header causes fetch to be served from the source ignoring cache options
claims.source_quote: if the request includes the cache-control: no-cache header, options.cache, options.next.revalidate, and options.next.tags are ignored, and the fetch request is served from the source

claims.statement: Browsers include cache-control: no-cache when developer tools cache is disabled or during hard refresh
claims.source_quote: Browsers typically include cache-control: no-cache when the cache is disabled in developer tools or during a hard refresh

claims.statement: Every utility class in Tailwind CSS can be applied conditionally at different breakpoints
claims.source_quote: Every utility class in Tailwind can be applied conditionally at different breakpoints, which makes it a piece of cake to build complex responsive interfaces without ever leaving your HTML

claims.source_quote: First, make sure you've added the viewport meta tag to the <head> of your document

claims.statement: The sm breakpoint corresponds to 40rem (640px) minimum width
claims.source_quote: sm | 40rem (640px) | @media (width >= 40rem) { ... }

claims.statement: The md breakpoint corresponds to 48rem (768px) minimum width
claims.source_quote: md | 48rem (768px) | @media (width >= 48rem) { ... }

claims.statement: The lg breakpoint corresponds to 64rem (1024px) minimum width
claims.source_quote: lg | 64rem (1024px) | @media (width >= 64rem) { ... }

claims.statement: The xl breakpoint corresponds to 80rem (1280px) minimum width
claims.source_quote: xl | 80rem (1280px) | @media (width >= 80rem) { ... }

claims.statement: The 2xl breakpoint corresponds to 96rem (1536px) minimum width
claims.source_quote: 2xl | 96rem (1536px) | @media (width >= 96rem) { ... }

claims.statement: Responsive variants can be applied to any utility class in Tailwind
claims.source_quote: This works for **every utility class in the framework**, which means you can change literally anything at a given breakpoint

claims.statement: Tailwind uses a mobile-first breakpoint system where unprefixed utilities apply to all screen sizes
claims.source_quote: Tailwind uses a mobile-first breakpoint system, similar to what you might be used to in other frameworks like Bootstrap

claims.statement: Prefixed utilities in Tailwind apply at the specified breakpoint and above
claims.source_quote: prefixed utilities (like `md:uppercase`) only take effect at the specified breakpoint *and above*

claims.statement: To style mobile in Tailwind, use unprefixed utilities not sm: prefixed ones
claims.source_quote: to style something for mobile, you need to use the unprefixed version of a utility, not the `sm:` prefixed version

claims.statement: Max variants can be stacked with responsive variants to target specific breakpoint ranges
claims.source_quote: Stack a responsive variant like `md` with a `max-*` variant to limit that style to a specific range

claims.statement: Breakpoints can be customized using theme variables like --breakpoint-*
claims.source_quote: Use the `--breakpoint-*` theme variables to customize your breakpoints

claims.statement: Tailwind uses rem unit for default breakpoints and should use rem for consistency
claims.source_quote: Tailwind uses `rem` for the default breakpoints, so if you are adding additional breakpoints to the defaults, make sure you use `rem` as well

claims.statement: Default breakpoints can be removed by resetting their value to the initial keyword
claims.source_quote: To remove a default breakpoint, reset its value to the `initial` keyword

claims.statement: Container queries let you style elements based on parent container size instead of viewport size
claims.source_quote: Container queries are a modern CSS feature that let you style something based on the size of a parent element instead of the size of the entire viewport

claims.statement: Use @container class to mark an element as a container and @sm/@md variants to style children
claims.source_quote: Use the `@container` class to mark an element as a container, then use variants like `@sm` and `@md` to style child elements based on the size of the container

claims.statement: Container queries are mobile-first in Tailwind and apply at target container size and above
claims.source_quote: Just like breakpoint variants, container queries are mobile-first in Tailwind CSS and apply at the target container size and up

entities.description: Low-level design decisions like typography, colors, shadows, and breakpoints
entities.quote: different designs need different typography, colors, shadows, breakpoints, and more

entities.name: Utility classes
entities.description: CSS classes generated from theme variables that can be used in HTML
entities.quote: using utility classes as an API for your design tokens

entities.name: CSS variables
entities.description: Standard CSS custom properties used to store and reference design token values
entities.quote: Tailwind also generates regular CSS variables for your theme variables

entities.name: Breakpoints
entities.description: Responsive design breakpoints defined in --breakpoint-* namespace for responsive variants
entities.quote: theme variables in the `--breakpoint-*` namespace determine which responsive breakpoint variants exist

entities.name: Color palette
entities.description: Set of colors defined in --color-* namespace for background, text, and other color utilities
entities.quote: includes the default color palette, type scale, shadows, fonts, and more

entities.description: Modern color space format used for defining Tailwind's default color palette
entities.quote: --color-mint-500: oklch(0.72 0.11 178)

entities.name: Container queries

entities.quote: `--container-*` | Container query variants like `@sm:*` and size utilities

entities.name: Shadow utilities
entities.description: Box shadow effects defined in --shadow-* namespace for drop shadows and inset shadows
entities.quote: --shadow-2xs: 0 1px rgb(0 0 0 / 0.05)

entities.name: Animation framework
entities.description: CSS animations defined via --animate-* namespace with @keyframes rules
entities.quote: Define the `@keyframes` rules for your `--animate-*` theme variables

entities.quote: the popular Motion library for React lets you animate to and from CSS variable values

The @theme directive enables definition of theme variables that influence utility classes
Theme variables influence which utility classes exist in your project
In Tailwind projects you store design token values in theme variables

claims.statement: Theme variables are CSS variables defined using the @theme directive that influence which utility classes exist
claims.source_quote: Theme variables are special CSS variables defined using the `@theme` directive that influence which utility classes exist in your project.

claims.statement: You can add a new color to your project by defining a theme variable like --color-mint-500
claims.source_quote: you can add a new color to your project by defining a theme variable like `--color-mint-500`

claims.statement: Tailwind generates regular CSS variables for theme variables so you can reference design tokens in arbitrary values
claims.source_quote: Tailwind also generates regular CSS variables for your theme variables so you can reference your design tokens in arbitrary values or inline styles

claims.statement: Theme variables must be defined top-level and not nested under other selectors or media queries
claims.source_quote: Theme variables are also required to be defined top-level and not nested under other selectors or media queries

claims.statement: The --font-* namespace determines all font-family utilities that exist in a project
claims.source_quote: theme variables defined in the `--font-*` namespace determine all of the `font-family` utilities that exist in a project

claims.statement: Defining a new --breakpoint-3xl theme variable makes the 3xl:* responsive variant available
claims.source_quote: Now you can use the `3xl:*` variant to only trigger a utility when the viewport is 120rem or wider

claims.statement: Theme variables are organized into namespaces that correspond to utility class and variant APIs
claims.source_quote: Theme variables are defined in namespaces and each namespace corresponds to one or more utility class or variant APIs.

claims.statement: Importing tailwindcss includes a set of default theme variables for colors, typography, shadows, fonts, and more
claims.source_quote: When you import `tailwindcss` at the top of your CSS file, it includes a set of default theme variables to get you started.

claims.statement: Utilities like bg-red-200, font-serif, and shadow-sm exist because of default theme variables, not hardcoded into the framework
claims.source_quote: This is why utilities like `bg-red-200`, `font-serif`, and `shadow-sm` exist out of the box — they're driven by the default theme, not hardcoded into the framework

claims.statement: You can extend the default theme by defining new theme variables using @theme directive
claims.source_quote: Use `@theme` to define new theme variables and extend the default theme

claims.statement: You can override a default theme variable by redefining it within @theme
claims.source_quote: Override a default theme variable value by redefining it within `@theme`

claims.statement: Setting --color-*: initial removes all default color utilities and allows only custom values
claims.source_quote: all of the default utilities that use that namespace (like bg-red-500) will be removed, and only your custom values

claims.statement: Setting --*: initial disables the entire default theme and allows only custom theme variables
claims.source_quote: To completely disable the default theme and use only custom values, set the global theme variable namespace to `initial`

claims.statement: You can define @keyframes rules for --animate-* theme variables within @theme to include them in generated CSS
claims.source_quote: Define the `@keyframes` rules for your `--animate-*` theme variables within `@theme` to include them in your generated CSS

claims.statement: Using the inline option makes utility classes use the theme variable value instead of referencing the actual variable
claims.source_quote: Using the `inline` option, the utility class will use the theme variable value instead of referencing the actual theme variable

claims.statement: By default only used CSS variables are generated in the final CSS output
claims.source_quote: By default only used CSS variables will be generated in the final CSS output

claims.statement: You can use the static theme option to always generate all CSS variables
claims.source_quote: If you want to always generate all CSS variables, you can use the `static` theme option

claims.statement: Theme variables can be shared across projects by defining them in a separate CSS file and importing with @import
claims.source_quote: Since theme variables are defined in CSS, sharing them across projects is just a matter of throwing them into their own CSS file that you can import in each project

claims.statement: All theme variables are turned into regular CSS variables when you compile your CSS
claims.source_quote: All of your theme variables are turned into regular CSS variables when you compile your CSS

claims.statement: You can use getComputedStyle to get the resolved value of a theme variable on the document root
claims.source_quote: If you need access to a resolved CSS variable value in JS, you can use `getComputedStyle` to get the value of a theme variable on the document root
